text: TITLE: Ardha Chakrasana (Half Spinal Twist) The standing backward bend involves arching the upper torso toward the rear. This pose focuses on stretching the front of the body and chest.

It helps to tone the muscles in the shoulders and the arms. The posture requires careful balancing while creating a gentle arc shape. Anyone with wrist, arm, or shoulder injuries should avoid this position.

Individuals with medical conditions that make balance difficult should not attempt it. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).

TITLE: Badhakonasana (Butterfly Pose) This sitting posture involves bringing the soles of the feet together and moving the knees up and down. It is highly effective for improving flexibility in the inner thighs and hip joints.

The movement helps to stimulate the abdominal organs and can aid in better digestion. Many people practice this pose to help relieve fatigue from long hours of standing. Individuals with knee or groin injuries should practice this very gently or avoid it.

It is not recommended to force the knees down if they do not reach the floor naturally. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Dhanurasana (Bow Pose) In the bow pose, you lie on your stomach and reach back to hold your ankles. This movement creates a shape that stretches the front of the body and the throat.

It is known for adding great flexibility to the back and strengthening the legs. The posture helps to massage the internal organs and improve digestive health. Avoid this pose if you have high blood pressure or a heart condition.

People with migraines or lower back injuries should not attempt this deep stretch. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Garudasana (Eagle Pose) The eagle pose requires wrapping the arms and legs together while balancing. It is designed to enhance coordination and improve overall body stability.

The posture stretches the upper back, shoulders, and outer thighs. It is an effective pose for developing deep focus and concentration. You should avoid this pose if you have neck pain or lower back issues.

Individuals with knee injuries should not practice the interlacing leg movement. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Hastapadasana (Standing Bend) This posture is a standing bend where the upper body folds toward the legs. It is designed to make the spine more supple and flexible over time.

The pose provides a deep stretch to all the muscles located along the back. It is known for helping to refresh and invigorate the nervous system. You should avoid this pose if you have chronic back or neck injuries.

People currently recovering from leg injuries should also refrain from this bend. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).

TITLE: Katichakrasana (Standing Spinal Twist) The standing spinal twist is a posture involving a gentle rotation of the waist. This movement helps to stretch the hips and the entire length of the spine.

It is particularly useful for building strength in the neck and shoulders. People with desk-bound jobs often find this pose helpful for relieving daily stiffness. Individuals with a hernia or heart conditions should skip this practice.

Those with existing spinal injuries or high blood pressure should avoid this twist. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).

TITLE: Konasana (Sideways Bending Pose) Konasana, also known as the sideways bending pose, is a simple standing yoga stretch. In this posture, one arm is lifted upward while the body gently bends to the side.
This movement supports balance and improves body coordination. It helps release tightness along the sides of the body and the spine. Many people practice this pose to support comfortable digestion.

Individuals with neck or hip injuries should avoid this pose. It is also not recommended for those experiencing high blood pressure or migraines. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Paschim_Namaskarasana (Reverse Prayer Pose) The reverse prayer pose involves joining the palms together behind the back. It is a great way to improve posture and open up the chest area.

This stretch targets the shoulders while helping to quiet the mind. A towel can be held between the hands if they do not comfortably meet. Individuals with shoulder injuries like rotator cuff issues should avoid this.
Ensure you move slowly into the position to avoid straining the joints. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).

TITLE: Pavanamuktasana (Wind-Relieving Pose) The wind-relieving pose involves lying on the back and hugging the knees to the chest. It is designed to massage the digestive organs and help release trapped gas.

This stretch helps to loosen the muscles in the lower back and the hips. It is a grounding movement that promotes a sense of physical ease. Avoid this pose if you have had recent abdominal surgery or a hernia.

Individuals with neck injuries should keep their heads on the floor during the stretch. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).

TITLE: Prasarita_Padahastasana (Wide Legged Forward Bend) In this pose, the feet are set wide apart as the torso bends toward the floor. It serves as a grounding posture that stretches the hamstrings and lower back.

This movement is often used to calm the mind and find relaxation. Blocks can be used to support the hands if the full bend is too intense. It is generally recommended to avoid this pose during the third trimester of pregnancy.

Individuals with acute lower back pain or knee injuries should skip this pose. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Shavasana (Corpse Pose) The corpse pose is a total relaxation position where you lie flat on your back. It is used to integrate the benefits of a yoga session and calm the body.

This pose reduces stress and helps to lower the heart rate naturally. It is a vital part of practice for restoring energy and mental clarity. Place a small pillow under your knees if you experience lower back discomfort.
Try to keep the body perfectly still to achieve a deep state of rest. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).

TITLE: Shishuasana (Child's Pose) This sitting posture involves bringing the soles of the feet together and moving the knees up and down. It is highly effective for improving flexibility in the inner thighs and hip joints.

The movement helps to stimulate the abdominal organs and can aid in better digestion. Many people practice this pose to help relieve fatigue from long hours of standing. Individuals with knee or groin injuries should practice this very gently or avoid it.

It is not recommended to force the knees down if they do not reach the floor naturally. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Sukhasana (Easy Pose) The easy pose is a simple cross-legged sitting position used for centering and breathing.  It helps to strengthen the back and improve overall body posture.

This position is widely used as a foundation for seated meditation and relaxation.  It encourages a sense of mental calm and reduces physical tiredness.  People with recent or chronic knee injuries should sit on a cushion for support.

Avoid sitting in this position for long periods if you experience lower back pain. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).

TITLE: Trikonasana (Triangle Pose) The triangle pose is created by spreading the legs and reaching one hand toward the ground. It is widely practiced to help improve both physical and mental stability.

This position can help reduce feelings of stress and general anxiety. Many find it useful for improving digestion and relieving minor back pain. Avoid this pose if you are currently experiencing dizziness or heart problems.

Individuals with recent injuries to the knees or hips should skip this stretch. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Utkatasana (Chair Pose) The chair pose mimics the action of sitting in a chair with the arms raised. It targets and strengthens the muscles in the legs, back, and core.

This posture helps build a sense of inner willpower and physical balance. Keep your weight in your heels to protect your joints while practicing. Avoid this pose if you have any recent injuries to the ankles or knees.
Those with chronic lower back pain should skip this strengthening exercise. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Virabhadrasana (Warrior Pose) The warrior pose is a standing lunge with the arms extended high overhead. It is an excellent posture for increasing stamina and strengthening the arms.

This pose is highly recommended for people with stiff or frozen shoulders. Practicing this regularly can help bring a sense of courage and grace. Those with high blood pressure or heart issues should avoid this vigorous pose.

People with chronic injuries to the knees or back should also refrain from it. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Vrikshasana (Tree Pose) The tree pose is a balance where one foot is placed against the opposite inner thigh. It is primarily used to develop better stability and mental concentration.

This posture strengthens the legs and helps open the hip joints. It may offer some relief to those dealing with discomfort from sciatica. People with vertigo or high blood pressure should avoid this balancing act.
Those with ankle or hip injuries should not attempt this one legged pose. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
Advanced yoga poses require strength, balance, and body awareness. Examples include Headstand and Handstand. These poses should only be practiced under expert guidance.
Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
Beginner yoga poses focus on stability, balance, and gentle stretching. Common beginner poses include Tadasana, Vajrasana, and Sukhasana. These poses are generally safe and help build flexibility.
Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).

Yoga should be practiced with caution during pregnancy, recent surgeries, or chronic illness. Certain inversions and intense poses may be unsafe. Consult a certified instructor or healthcare professional when unsure.
Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Kapalbhati Pranayama A breathing technique involving forceful exhalations and passive inhalations. It helps improve digestion and energize the body.
Should be avoided during pregnancy or recent surgery. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
TITLE: Nadi Shodhana (Alternate Nostril Breathing) This breathing practice involves slow, controlled breathing through alternate nostrils. It helps calm the nervous system and reduce stress.
Avoid if you have severe respiratory infections or nasal blockage. Source: Summarized from Art of Living (https://www.artofliving.org/in-en/yoga/beginners/beginner-yoga-asanas-for-everyday).
